channel.title: GIT Version Control System :: Helm
channel.description: ğŸ§¾ What is Git? Git is a free, open-source, and distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency. ğŸ”§ In Simple Terms Git helps track changes in your code (or any files), collaborate with others, and go back in time to previous versions. ğŸ§ Key Features of Git Feature Description âœ… Distributed Every developer has a full copy of the repository. â³ Version Tracking Keeps a history of every change (who, what, when, and why). ğŸ§ª Branching & Merging Create isolated environments (branches), and combine them when ready. âš¡ Fast & Efficient Designed to be fast â€” especially for large projects. ğŸ” Secure Uses checksums (SHA-1) to ensure data integrity. ğŸ“¦ Git vs GitHub Git GitHub Version control tool (CLI) Web-based platform for Git repositories Works locally Requires internet/browser for collaboration Can be used independently Built on top of Git ğŸ“‚ Real-World Analogy Imagine writing a book:

item.title: Git
item.description: ğŸš€ Git Tutorial from Start â€” With Real-Time Examples ğŸ“˜ Table of Contents ğŸš€ Git Tutorial from Start â€” With Real-Time Examples ğŸ“˜ Table of Contents ğŸ“Œ What is Git? ğŸ§° Installing Git For Linux: For macOS: For Windows: âš™ï¸ Git Configuration ğŸ”„ Basic Git Workflow ğŸ§¬ Cloning a Repository âœï¸ Making Changes & Committing ğŸŒ¿ Branching and Merging ğŸ”„ Real-Time Example: Feature Branch Workflow ğŸ“¦ Stashing Changes ğŸŒ Working with Remotes ğŸ“œ Git Log and History ğŸ”™ Undoing Things ğŸš« .gitignore File ğŸ·ï¸ Git Tags âœ… Conclusion ğŸ“Œ What is Git? Git is a distributed version control system. Tracks changes in source code during software development. Helps teams collaborate on code. ğŸ§° Installing Git For Linux: sudo apt update sudo apt install git For macOS: brew install git For Windows: Download from: https://git-scm.com/downloads âš™ï¸ Git Configuration git config --global user.name "Your Name" git config --global user.email "you@example.com" git config --list # verify settings ğŸ”„ Basic Git Workflow git init # Initialize a Git repository git status # Check current status git add file.txt # Stage a file git commit -m "Added file" # Commit with message ğŸ§¬ Cloning a Repository git clone https://github.com/yourusername/project.git âœï¸ Making Changes & Committing echo "Hello Git" > hello.txt git add hello.txt git commit -m "Added hello.txt file" ğŸŒ¿ Branching and Merging git branch # List branches git branch feature-x # Create a new branch git checkout feature-x # Switch to branch # Make changes and commit git checkout main git merge feature-x # Merge branch into main ğŸ”„ Real-Time Example: Feature Branch Workflow Scenario: You are adding a login feature.

item.title: Git Logs
item.description: ğŸ” Advanced git log Examples git log is highly customizable. Here are real-world examples: ğŸ“¦ Basic Commit Log git log Shows full commit history with author, date, and message. ğŸ§µ One-line Log (Condensed View) git log --oneline Shows each commit as a single line: useful for quick scanning. ğŸŒ² Visual Branch Graph git log --oneline --graph --all Displays commit history as a branch graph across all branches.

item.title: Git More Examples
item.description: ğŸ“œ Git Log and History git log git log --oneline git log --oneline --graph --all ğŸ”™ Undoing Things git checkout -- file git revert <commit> ğŸ§ Understanding git reset git reset --soft HEAD~1 # Keep changes staged git reset --mixed HEAD~1 # Keep changes, unstage git reset --hard HEAD~1 # Discard changes ğŸ” Advanced git log Examples git log # Full history git log --oneline # Short view git log --graph --oneline # Tree view git log --author="name" git log --since="7 days ago" git log -p # Show diffs git log --stat # File changes git log -1 --name-only # Files in last commit git log --merges # Only merge commits ğŸš« .gitignore File *.log .env node_modules/ .idea/ ğŸ·ï¸ Git Tags git tag v1.0 git tag -a v1.1 -m "Release v1.1" git push origin --tags âœ… Conclusion Use Git daily. Learn branching, logs, reset, and collaboration with remotes. Practice makes perfect!

item.title: Git Rebase and Merge
item.description: ğŸ§© Git Merge Methods Explained ğŸ”¸ 1. Fast-Forward Merge ğŸ“Œ What: Moves the branch pointer forward because thereâ€™s no divergent history. ğŸ§ª Example: git checkout main git merge feature-branch âœ… If main is behind feature-branch but has no new commits, Git just moves main forward â€” no merge commit is created. ğŸ“Š Result: No extra commit. Clean history. Only possible when histories are linear (no parallel commits). ğŸ”¸ 2. Three-Way Merge (Default) ğŸ“Œ What: Used when branches diverged â€” Git creates a merge commit.
